awd_titl_txt: New Advanced Time Integration Methods for Multiphysics Systems and Applications
awd_abstract_narration:
Many important systems in science and engineering involve multiple physical processes. Complex interactions between these components can result in dynamics over a wide range of time scales, and this feature poses significant challenges for computational simulations. Prominent examples come from the vastly differing time scales in atmospheric phenomena, a central issue of numerical weather prediction (NWP) and climate modeling. Similar challenges arise in computational modeling of dynamics of coupled oscillators such as fibers, fluids, or flexible solids, with many applications in animation and medical imaging. The goal of this project is to develop new fast and accurate time integration methods for complex coupled models and to apply them to NWP and climate simulations as well as to other examples. On the educational side, the project will directly involve and train one doctoral student, as well as offer research opportunities to other undergraduate and graduate students in mathematics.

This project considers general coupled multiphysics systems. The goal is to develop new advanced exponential Rosenbrock/Runge-Kutta and multi-rate time integration methods for multiphysics models. The project has three research objectives. First, the PI plans to derive new parallel and adaptive exponential methods for stiff multiphysics systems. With this in place, the PI aims to derive new time-stepping methods that have optimized structures and local error control for efficiency. Second, the PI plans to develop a complete theory for constructing two new classes of multirate methods for partitioned multiphysics systems. Third, building on existing codes and ongoing collaborations with numerical analysts, meteorologists, and computer scientists, the PI will investigate the performance of newly-developed methods on applications mentioned previously.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project focused on developing advanced time integration methods for solving systems of differential equations that arise in science and engineering, particularly those involving multiple physical processes evolving at different time scales. These problems are difficult to simulate efficiently because of stiffness, where extremely fast processes interact with slower ones. Such behavior is common in areas like weather prediction, climate modeling, biological systems, fluid dynamics, and visual computing.

Originally impacted by delays due to the COVID-19 pandemic in 2020-2021 (the first year of the project), the project was extended through a no-cost extension and eventually achieved its original goals.

Intellectual Merit

The project successfully achieved its two primary aims:

1. Theoretical and computational development of advanced time integration methods:

  • New high-order parallel exponential Runge-Kutta/Rosenbrock methods were constructed and implemented for stiff partial differential equations (PDEs).
  • The first-ever adaptive exponential Runge-Kutta methods for stiff PDEs were developed, along with the first sixth-order exponential Runge-Kutta methods for such systems.
  • A second-order two-derivative exponential method (TDEXP2) was designed for genetic regulatory systems, demonstrating improved simulation capability in computational biology.
  • A new class of high-order two-derivative exponential Runge-Kutta/Rosenbrock methods was introduced in the final project year, showing clear advantages in simulating stiff reaction-diffusion systems with extremely stiff nonlinearities.
  • High-order two-derivative DIRK methods were derived with optimized phase errors, targeting problems with oscillatory dynamics.
  • Multirate Exponential Rosenbrock Methods (MERB), a novel high-order class of integrators for multiphysics problems was proposed that allow different parts of a system to evolve at their own natural time scales, dramatically reducing computation time. The corresponding codes are publicly available on GitHub.
  • Adaptive time-stepping strategies for multirate exponential methods were also developed. 

2. Demonstration of the performance of the newly developed methods on applications:

  • Parallel-stage and superconvergent exponential Rosenbrock schemes developed in this project were successfully applied to visual computing applications (in collaboration with a computer scientist from KAUST), such as simulating deformable bodies and physical interactions (e.g., crash scenarios). See the attached figures.
  • The new second-order two-derivative exponential method and other high-order exponential schemes combined with a special splitting technique (developed in this project) were successfully applied to the simulation of genetic regulatory models in computational biology. See the attached figures.
  • Two-derivative exponential Runge-Kutta and Rosenbrock methods developed in this project have been tested on benchmark applications, including the 2D shallow water model and 2D/3D compressible Euler equations, which are commonly used in numerical weather prediction (NWP). The initial results are promising, and collaborative work with a researcher from Environment Canada is ongoing to further evaluate these new methods. See the attached figure.

Dissemination and Publications:

The findings of the project were published in high-quality journals such as SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, Applied Mathematics and Computation, Applied Mathematics Letters, BIT Numerical Mathematics, and the Journal of Computational and Applied Mathematics, as well as in a book chapter published by Springer. In addition, multiple manuscripts have been submitted or are in preparation for submission to SIAM Journal on Numerical Analysis, SIAM Journal on Scientific Computing, and the Journal of Computational Physics. Moreover, the code package "MERB: Multirate Exponential Rosenbrock Methods" is publicly available on GitHub at https://github.com/rujekoc/merbrepo.

Broader Impacts

Beyond its scientific contributions, the project made meaningful impacts in education and training:

  • It directly supported the research of two PhD students from underrepresented backgrounds, one of whom completed their PhD and is now an Assistant Professor.
  • It engaged a third PhD student and two undergraduate students through an NSF- REU program at MSU, helping develop the next generation of researchers in computational mathematics.
  • It led to the creation of lecture notes for a new graduate course on time integration methods, helping translate up-to-date research into classroom teaching. 

The project also established valuable collaborations and partnerships among institutions, including Mississippi State University, Southern Methodist University, Environment and Climate Change Canada, and King Abdullah University of Science and Technology, helping to bring new methods into real-world scientific and engineering applications.

Overall, this project has significantly advanced the state of the art in time-integration methods for stiff and multiphysics systems and contributed meaningfully to both theoretical development and real-world applications across scientific disciplines. It also trained a diverse group of young researchers and promoted international collaboration.
